subject: Re: [junit] reg. JUnit
msgSnippet: Hi Pallavi, I have tried out a example in Division , I m not sure how far its efficient and clearing ur doubts but jus take a look at it : regds chandu Test
messageBody:
Hi Pallavi,

I have tried out a example in Division , I'm not sure how far its efficient
and clearing ur doubts but jus take a look at it :
regds
chandu

Test program for Division :
=======================

// author - chandu
import junit.framework.*;
import java.util.*;

public class TestDivide extends TestCase
{
private Divide dvd=new Divide();

public void testDivide()
{
assertEquals(4,dvd.division(24,6));
try
{
//Divide dvd1= new Divide();
dvd.division(19,0);
dvd.division(20,50);
fail("Test Failing");
}catch( RuntimeException e) { }
}

public static Test suite()
{
return new TestSuite(TestDivide.class);
}

public static void main (String args[])
{
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
}
}

Actual program
==========
//author chandu
import java.util.*;

public class Divide {

public int division(int a, int b) throws RuntimeException
{ if( (b>a)||(b==0) ) throw new RuntimeException("Invalid divisiors");
return a/b;

}
}




On Monday 15 September 2003 3:51 pm, David wrote:
> Pallavi,
>
> Here you will find some basic example about how to use junit:
>
> http://junit.sourceforge.net/#Documentation
>
> Regards,
>
> David
> -----Mensaje original-----
> De: pallavi metla [mailto:pallavi28183@...]
> Enviado el: viernes, 12 de septiembre de 2003 6:05
> Para: junit@...
> Asunto: [junit] reg. JUnit
>
>
> Hi everybody,
>
> As a part of my Masters, I am supposed to learn JUnit. I went through
> some of the basic papers as JUnit Test Infected, junit cook book etc. but
> am not understanding the correct use of that.
>
> Like if I create a simple program like addition of two integers and want
> to pass the values of a and b to be some (i.e., generating the test cases),
> how can I do using the JUnit. I created a JUnit program "TestAddInt.java
> "with a testAdd() method in that compared the resultant value of a and b
> with the expected value but its something like I took the values a and b as
> ints..TestAddInt.java but am not understanding how to bring the values of
> the original java program "AddInt.java"??
>
> I am pretty sure that if someone give a simple example, I will learn the
> rest. So I would be thankful if someone helps me out.
>
> Regards,
> Pallavi
>
